cons: Management continuously erodes employee compensation. Employee morale is at an all time low. Workers are given unrealistic job expectations to meet due to downsizing and then told that compensation is cut because Dell is a "meritocracy". There is no longer such a thing as "work-life" balance, yet senior management seems surprised that there is a mass exodus of long term employees jumping ship.
advice: Look back at what originally made Dell great -- the workers. Stop focusing so much on impressing wall street with a turn around story.
pros: The best reason to work at Dell is as a resume builder to get a job with a better company. It has often been said that Dell is a good "first or third" place to work, but not somewhere from which you retire.
summary: Run from Dell!

cons: The managers don't care about you as an individual, you are treated like a number. They just fire people knowing more will apply.
advice: Treat employees with respect.
pros: The benefits, but they don't outway the cons.
summary: Dell Hell

cons: The management team had no idea what to do when the times got tough other than cut heads. They got the company into the terrible mess it was in by being uncreative, irresponsible and uncompassionate about what impact their same decisions to do the same things over and over again have on employees and their families. It always was a tough place to work, which isnt bad when the compensation matches and you are being re… warded for the hard work. They didnt care about anything other than hitting the number. When no one could figure out what or why the business wasnt doing well they repspond with even more ludicrous goals that nobody will be able to hit. Equivalent to just completing a mile run in 4 minutes, then they turn around and want you to run the mile in 2 minutes with a straight face.
advice: Take some responsibility for the negative culture that they created. You have bled and chased off the most professional and talented pool of sales and management team that I have ever worked with; now you are left with people who are either too desparate that cant quit, or with managers and people that are still just interested in a golden parachute that still cant figure out how they got into the mess into the first…  place, let alone how they will get out of it. You have ruined a great company by unrealistic goals, uncreative people and absolutely zero compassion for any person who gives their best to the company.
pros: It did provide a solid education about the direct business model and great supply chain management. Most of my peers were people I respected and worked extremely hard to be successful in a difficult environment.
summary: How to chase off your best talent

cons: The culture at Dell is terrible. The environment is similar to the military in that people are supposed to just do what they are told without question and without thinking. It is a very top down driven company, which stifles creativity, great ideas, and even common sense business decisions. "just do what you're told"In addition, there is no respect for work life balance. Everyone is expected to work long hour… s and weekends---then head home and work on email. All companies demand long hours from their workers, but one major difference at Dell is that people spend all this time working on valueless activities just because some exec or manager said so.The leadership is terrible with no clear direction and strategy. The company is in a death seizure, where it is flopping from one strategy to the next. The company is controlled from the top and has hired very few good leaders and a work force that only knows how to take orders. This creates only ideas that are "me too", where Dell has become a company that only copies others---now both in process and product.The company is really broken from all sides. The infrastructure (IT, Phone, SW) has been underfunded and neglected. The workforce moral is terrible and the leadership (and pipeline) are completely inept. There is no clear process or standards for anything, which creates tons of bureaucracy and inefficiencies. I'm surprised the company is doing as well as it is. Don't be fooled by the lies and spin---it is a terrible culture and company.
advice: Get rid of Michael Dell, rehire true leaders, and decide a strategy and stick to it.
pros: Dell is a fast paced work environment in an exciting industry.Austin is a great town with very low cost of living.
summary: Dell is a terrible place to work.

cons: The bureacracy; the fact that no one individual can make a decision without having a meeting about it; how poorly employees are treated by their supervisors. This company will work you to the brink of exhaustion and then expect more from you - if you want a bonus.
advice: Start treating employees like human beings or you will continue to have difficulty hiring and retaining good people.
pros: They have cafeterias in some of the buildings...???
summary: Stay away from Dell if you want a satisfying job and the opportunity for a career.

cons: The substandard pay, slowly diminishing benefits, and general negative atmosphere create a frustrating workplace, but those aren't what bother me most. The fact that the most important criteria is how long a person has been in their current position for promotions is aggravating. It ends up making all supervisory and managerial positions fill with people who aren't qualified to get jobs elsewhere so they stuck with D… ell, while all good employees get fed up with this and leave.If you're thinking of joining, be sure you get hired at where you're qualified to be hired, pay-wise. If you get in too low, you won't be able to skip pay grades and will need to be in each pay grade for at least a year. I've known many people who quit because of this.The tools and software used for the job are pitiful. Half the time they are down, and when they are up they resemble something a high school student put together 20 years ago.The company claims the customer is important, but all support contracts are poorly written, intentionally misleading, and leading to numerous lawsuits. Beyond this, employees are constantly insulting customers while they're on hold to one-another.There is no managerial support to get unhappy employees to stay, regardless of how well employees are doing. Wages for new hires are constantly falling lower and lower below industry average, while Dell explains this by saying the "great" benefits make up for it.If you are at all driven, want to get ahead, and work hard then do not, for any reason, under any circumstances, apply for Dell tech support, it's the worst thing you can do for your career.
advice: Emphasize performance and accomplishments rather than seniority for "promotions." Better yet, implement promotions rather just allowing employees to apply for certain jobs when their time in their current one is long enough. Have front line managers get to know their employees and what their employees are supposed to be doing day-to-day.
pros: The company does make some aesthetically pleasing computer products. There are also a lot of very fun to work with employees at the company. Having tuition reimbursement is nice.
summary: Look elsewhere for a career

cons: They lie to you. Micro managed. Promised things that dont happen. Treated like a piece of meat. pressured to work a lot of overtime that you are not fairly compensated for. Screwed out of spiffs. Pressured to use dishonest sales techniques.
advice: Clean house and start over with the type of people who run Strabucks or Chick file'. Instead of trying to stick a cattle prod up every reps rectum to squeeze one more hour out of them, treat them like truly valued assets and recognize that a good days work is nothing to be ashamed of.
pros: You are a used car salesman type which means you can make pretty good commissions until they shut the plant down.
summary: Dell Leadership the Problem, But Employees Take the Punishment

cons: They lie, cheat, work you to death for no reason, etc.
advice: Don't lie your way into getting someone to sign on - chances are if they are good enough for you to lie to their face, they are good enough to get a job elsewhere and you just spent major bucks training them for no reason.
pros: There are none except for its a job if you don't have one. But at this point I would choose to be unemployed over working at Dell.
summary: Worst job ever.

cons: Employee are not respected. The only time Senior Management will talk to you is to let you go. Beware of one on one meeting with senior Management. You will use old and obsolete technologies. My experience with DELL was for me a dead end job, part of a losing team with no possibility of grow. Most of my time was spend in meeting, talking on the phone, replying to email and creating reports for management that no one … care reading.
advice: Listen employees and stop treat them like they worth less than nothing.
pros: I had the chance to work with different cultures.
summary: Worst experience ever

cons: One was treated like if one were ignorant and a slave.
advice: You do not communicate timely and you treat people like your servants implying that they should be thankful they have a job.
pros: If you are in need of overtime.
summary: learn from the experience and find a respectful company who treats people like human beings.

cons: Extremely limited career growth. Like IBM of old, Dell employees have to wait for someone up the line to leave in order to be promoted. Recent requirements for management scope and layering mean that many people who could grow their careers in leadership opportunities cannot do so.Very constrained innovation environment. The focus on cost continues, at the expense of pleasing the customer.
advice: Turn in your badge and leave. Take your stock options and just go. So many talented people behind you; just go
pros: AustinMany people are out the door at 5Brand recognition on the resumeRemarkably good work / life balance
summary: Squandered opportunity

cons: Just about everything else...I've been rated good or best every year but I'm still the same level that I was 13 years ago.Management is deeply involved in every decision but makes them without the experts or data in the room...and never tells employees their decisions until some issue comes up with it that the employee has to fix.Senior leadership is lost in the wilderness. There is no diligence to findin… g out what's wrong and working to fix it. Everthing is a blind shot in the dark based on "gut feel".
advice: Get back to basic execution. Stop following the next shiny object or new toy. HP has not been kicking our tail with new niche products...they have been executing on the mainstream products.
pros: I love the computer industry. It's a hobby as much as a job.
summary: Great pay but not worth the money. Skip it, if you're looking.

cons: Dell failed to invest in infrastructure as the company grew. There are no processes or tools which makes each and every job very difficult, very manual, and inefficient. You spend most of your time focusing on the trivial many instead of the important few.
advice: Focus on profitability.
pros: Very talented and high caliber employees that you interact with, although good people seem to be leaving every day.
summary: Turnaround Taking Time

cons: I worked 60 hours a week on my last project. They eliminated my team a day after a launch.
advice: Respect your employees.
pros: Can't tell you. I had a great work group. Supportive manager (at first) but still ended my career at Dell by getting worked over by management. Unfortunate.
summary: Avoid Dell as an employer in this economy

cons: Very poor planning from the top on down. Strategic areas for the business are identified but long-term objectives and programs are not clearly defined. Results in a "flavor of the month" environment with shifting priorities and due dates. If you need support from other teams to complete a project - good luck! You may have commitment from them for now, but that could fall away overnight. Successful management and comp… letion of projects is a rarity. A very frustrating environment.
advice: Get more involved in projects and programs, and lend support to see that they get completed. Kill off those programs that don't add the necessary value.
pros: On the job learning opportunities are great because of the chaos that reigns. Have to be creative and figure out how to work the system and get around roundblocks on an ongoing basis!
summary: Driving the business in the ground in order to do leveraged buyout?

cons: Poisonous and combative work environment. Enemies are all within, not the competition. Kill or be killed is the way to be seen. Zero loyalty. Ex-pats do not advance (despite sr. management reassurances) and often don't have a home when they return. Innovation is squashed. True respect does not exist.
advice: Get rid of Michael (sorry - you may be a legend but your style no longer works) and begin to change the culture. Highly reward innovation and creative thought. Get rid of the "antibodies" that attack all new things.
pros: Good pay, interesting products, very good global experiences and global management opportunities.
summary: Good pay and looks interesting from the outside, but the old fun Dell does not exist and has become a poisonous trap.

cons: Because of the downsizing and lack of growth there is little to no advancement opportunities. Finance controls your compensation via quotas, which leads to very unrealistic quotas. There's little to no training unless you do it online and who has time for that when you're chasing a huge quota? The current management that's left doesn't have a clue how to manage since they were never trained and treat senior outside s… ales people like they're inside sales reps. Options are all but worthless and they did away with the employee stock purchase plan. Dell will not allow you to interview with vendor partners which severely limits any opportunity to better yourself unless you quit first.
advice: Somebody needs to realize that people make up a company, along with products and services. If you treat your employees badly they will in turn not care about customers. Why keep the lousy VP's, Directors, RSM's, etc. and let the better ones go? Sure, they've been successful and now struggle to make their numbers but they're also the ones that got you where you needed to be when times were better. No wonder they're le… aving in droves.
pros: It used to be a great place to work. As previous comments have said, there were lots of reasons to be here 9 to 10 years ago but it's not much more than a job now. Most of my best managers and good friends have left for other companies and the rest of us are treated like we're a drag to the bottom line.
summary: Certainly not what it used to be

cons: The management is incompetent. They are racist, sexist and very much a good boys club. They lean on employees and most of them do nothing. Good luck getting promotions and credit for what you do. Unless of course you drink or play golf with the right people.
advice: All of you should quit.
pros: Work life balance is very good. You usually are pretty flexible. The company feels young. It has a refreshing casual feel. It can feel like a cool place to work. You have a chance to make impact on the business and see results. You can expect to get great benefits (though those have worsened) and great vacation time. The DELL perks are also very good.
summary: DFS it could have been a great place, if it wasn't for the management.

cons: If you have a social life (or want a social life), find some place else to work. During my eight plus years at Dell, the emphasis was ALWAYS Dell first; your family, friends, etc. were always a distant second. Work/Life balance is an EXTREMELY bad joke unless you either work in one of the administrative divisions of Dell or you are a C-level or higher manager. Work schedules can (and often are changed) with less than…  24 hours notice and overtime is always considered "scheduled time" (aka MANDATORY).The primary motivational tool that Dell management uses can be summed up in one word: FEAR and the management team knows how to use this "tool" to the fullest of its ability.When head count reductions are needed, the people that are on work restrictions (most of the time because of medical conditions caused by the job) are normally targeted.More often than not the facilities and equipment are poorly maintained combine this with long shifts for many days in a row and these are the leading causes of work related injuries.The most common medical conditions for Dell employees are bad knees, bad feet, stress or depression and every admitting nurse in Austin normally asks a question to this affect when they see Dell on the employees insurance card.Management is a joke. Almost all of the lower level managers are either fresh out of college with no management experience (and in many cases no people skills) or new from a different industry with no idea about the Dell corporate culture. During my time a Dell, I only know of five people that were promoted to the management ranks from the production floor.Dell tells all of their new hires that promotions are based on Merit. This has been an out right lie since November 2000 when Dell changed the promotion policies from merit to a policy based seniority, skill sets and "office politics" (stick your favorite cliche between the quotes).
advice: If you wish to regain your title as the Number One PC maker in the world, you need to return to emphasizing producing quality products with great customer service and technical support.Instead of recruiting new managers from outside of Dell, promote people from the lower ranks that already know the corporate culture and those that are willing to help Dell regain it's former status.Start treating your people l… ike they are "assets" not "resources". We are not machines, robots or parts that come from the suppliers every two hours. We are humans.
pros: There are only two good reasons to work for Dell's manufacturing and distribution division. The first is a steady paycheck every two weeks. The second is an okay benefits package; not a great benefits package but not as bad as some.
summary: If your are considering a job with Dell, RUN like the Devil is chasing you, because HE IS!!!!!

cons: Incompetent and unethical senior management and board of directors. Michael's last name is on the building and he runs the company like a dictatorship. He tells his "leaders" what to do, they tell their managers what to do, and so on. There is zero tolerance for anyone to question or challenge anything Michael wants to do. See the long list of departed executives who have tried to suggest improving the company. This … culture impacts the entire company -- if you are not a "yes man" you will be miserable working at Dell. I've never met an employee who wants to stay at Dell for the long run.
advice: Dell is horribly positioned for the direction that the industry is moving. Michael Dell may be the only one in the IT industry that doesn't understand that virtualization, thin client, and cloud computing will make PCs, servers, and laptops a zero profit commodity. Dell is not even trying to position itself for the inevitable future, where the only value-added parts of IT are software and services. Michael believes t… hat cutting costs is a strategy. It is not.
pros: There are a wide range of jobs available at Dell and most managers provide employees with the flexibility to try new things. Moving up can be difficult but Dell is a pretty good place to gain broad experience. Most employees stay at Dell (in spite of the downsides) because Austin is a great city.
summary: OK place to gain experience, but don't plan on making Dell a final career destination.

cons: The stress, especially for those in customer facing roles. Opportunities for advancement do not exist anymore. One always has to be on guard because ever since the first round of layoffs the needs of the business will outweigh yours. Promotions do not go to the most qualified. Brown nosers seem to do the best. Having Dell on your resume just isn't what it used to be. Sometimes multitasking isn't the most efficient wa… y to be doing things.No raise this year but I guess that is ok Dell needs that nickel more than I do
advice: You are all fired! Management puts on the big show to suck up to the street and to the media but but seem stuck in a frame of mind that it is still 1999. There needs to be an injection of New Blood with new big ideas to turn things around. Bring back quality to the products. Listen to what the customers really want not what you think they will want and maybe they will buy a system from Dell rather than Apple or HP or…  Acer.
pros: Some of the people that work there are great people to be around. The pay is not great but just ok. My now overpriced medical insurance. There is more available parking these days.
summary: Dark days ahead and the ship is taking on water, where are the rats?

cons: No leadership. No trust. No growth. No constructive work. No respect. Backstabbers everywhere and ass kissers all along the management chain. Get ready to brown your nose if you want in... btw- you'll be ankle deep in it and head first no less! For the love of humanity, just say no to (D)HELL!
advice: Do something like fire yourself or at least place yourself on a PIP (Performance Improvement Plan) and return your compensation+bonus for stinking it up. Stop talking and earn your pay. You're not entitled to STEAL that paycheck while doing nothing.
pros: It pays the bills right now.
summary: No leadership, no direction, no respect, no growth equates to a huge dead zone in central TX where careers go to die!

cons: Invisible management, office politics like I've never seen before, and the only way I knew I was fired was that my badge didn't work anymore. The jockeying for position to be seen by management when they do show their faces is ridiculous. I felt like I was in high school again. I've never EVER seen so many people try and throw co-workers under the bus in my life. it was almost a sport to them.
advice: Try answering emails and phone calls from the people under you. They are there for a reason.
pros: The compensation package was very satisfying. The cafe had good food. There are very cool and talented people working there. The ones not trying to stab you in the back, that is.
summary: Dell: In it for the money.

cons: Lack of Strategy and vision. Excessively focused in short term performance and lose sight of the longer term picture. No value for people, culture, loyalty. Uncompetitive and inconsistent pay structure. No focus on grooming talent internally and providing them growth opportunities.
advice: Need to get a focused strategy and vision. Employees are assets and need to be valued more.
pros: Experience in a global setup. Exposure to top class operations and supply chain. Opportunities to learn. Fast paced work environment. Opportunities to move within groups and functions.
summary: Good for learning but lack of career growth

cons: constant fear of being laid off, continually reducing employee benefits, extreme frustration amongst employees regarding the extravagant compensation packagages offered to senior execs and outrageous exit packages when they're fired
advice: apprecaiate and value your employees much more than you do today. . Frustration toward executives and fear off layoffs are dramatically impacting productivity.
pros: good pay, talented employees, lots of flex time
summary: Burn out employer, be forewarned

cons: management is not interested in outside of Dell experience nor are they interested in what you did at Dell before taking on whatever role you are currently in.
advice: Have a 1x1 more than once a year. Allow for leadership opportunities from the front line. Focus on developing your people instead of only driving to a number
pros: Great place for getting paid if you started more than 3 years ago for growth. under the right department, you can also progress with your career
summary: Looking for greener pastures

cons: Good people strangled by management caprice. Frustrating place to work.
advice: Too much middle management. Organizational structures do not complement each other because there is no clear definition of relative responsibilities. Decisions such in review gridlock as people are not empowered.
pros: Company has lots of market opportunity to grow
summary: Opportunity comes with frustration

cons: Way to many assigned accounts. Unrealistic quotas. My manager has 36 direct reports. As a result he can't manage people or the business he can only manage for exceptions (meaning you dont want to get on anyones radar).I wish the job market was better so i could quit.
advice: I am so down on Dell management. In my situation my dell manager has more headcount than a person could realistically manage. Hard for me to give advice.
pros: Dell gives you alot of freedom and the tools to build your business. As Long as you make your number you dont get to much grief. If you dont make your # start looking for a new job asap. Sometimes you dont have alot of contol over your quota and how realitic it is in terms of the current economy. Essentially Dell as a company doesn't want to hear excuse. They want to get paid.

cons: Our company was purchased by Dell, with the intent of fully integrating the company into the Dell structure. There was very poor or non-existent communication with regard to which positions would be kept and which would be eliminated.
advice: Allow for more informal procedures for everyday problem solving. For example, the simplest desktop PC problems require entering a trouble ticket, which is often routed to an offshore team.
pros: Good benefits, including vacation, health and vacation. Quick responses to HR questions. Opportunities to purchase Dell hardware at a discount.
summary: Poor communication

cons: A great raise is 3%, however in 2009 no raises were given.85% of all work will be sent offshore to India, the Phillipines and soon to be China.Having to train your offshore replacement and then be seperated from the company.No communication from Senior Management.
advice: Respect and listen to your associates. You will only be as successful as they make you!
pros: The relationships I made with my peers.
summary: Want to Lose your job to someone in India and not receive adequate pay? If yes, Dell Perot Systems is right for you!

cons: They believe they are a meritocracy. I worked in half a dozen groups over 10 years. That may have been true early on. Its simply not anymore.
advice: Dell used to believe in high quality products, fantastic customer service, and they used to place a high value on their employees. Somewhere along the line they lost sight of those three basics and decided that customers will buy a Dell no matter what and that employees were interchangeable head counts. Now they continually lose both and that won't change until they change their culture to make those three basics imp… ortant again.
pros: They have a pretty lax dress code.
summary: Not happy with Dell

cons: - Like many others that have commented in reviews, compensation is on the low side- Pay scale structure is complex and designed to justify keeping you at a lower salary- Performance reviews are a joke and bogus! Managers are given "quotas" of employees they need to "fit" in the respective performance categories.- Promotions with a pay raise are non-existent. You are given more and additional responsibilit… ies but no corresponding pay raise.- Don't ever get close to the bench.
advice: Reward people for their performance and honestly and objectively evaluate and categorize your associates. If you claim to attain to the "most respected IT organization in the industry" you can only get there with a majority of talented, distinguished, and exceptional team members. I'm talking front line folks too, and not just top heavy management. Make your performance rating curves reflect this reality. The majorit… y of your employess are "distinguished and exceptional", not just successful or partially successful. This attitude toward your performance ratings is making your best people leave or actively looking to leave at the first available opportunity and you will likely be at the point where your bell curves will eventually reflect the reality you are currently portraying!
pros: - Great team members- Genuinely good people and talented associates- Fitness center on site- Buddy up with senior management to progress
summary: Poor Compensation, Bogus Performance Reviews, Worthless Values Card

cons: low pay, no bonuses, incompetent management, lack of education and training but an expected to implement anyway, lack of support from management, unrealistic SLAs, being asked to work overtime off the clock without pay, being paged every 15 minutes for a bogus alert and still expected to respond, unethical company, asked to lie, lack of trust between management and employees, people being terminated with no cause, hi… gh turnover rate, employees not being able to discuss issues for fear of being terminated. They give you a values card........don't believe one word of it.
advice: go back to working at Burger King or whever it was you were working before. Technology is not the same industry and should not be managed the same. The clients hate you, the employees hate you. Does that give you a clue?

summary: If you like bad management at it's finest, want no bonuses, pay increases, lack of values then this is the place to work

cons: Employee morale down the tubesQuality nonexistentCustomer service deemed too expensiveJust about everything outsourced, Dell doesn't actually make much themselves anymore
advice: Resign, that's the best advice I can give all upper management. You are the people who have ruined this once great company, you are the ones that need to go instead of the loyal employees you have laid off by the tens of thousands.
pros: Austin area is a great place to beWorking hours are fairly flexible for some positionsA place to learn while on your way to a better position elsewhere

cons: In two years we went through 3 different business plans, and 4 different incentive programs. Each cutting into the amount of target incentives we could obtain.Dell owns you, you will have no outside life because of schedule conflicts. expect 60 hour work weeks, and six days a week with as little as one day notice.No chance of seeing your children, even though management has you working 8 to 8 they will still … slip out early to get their kids home...
advice: pick a course and stick with it. half the time the employees haven't a clue because management is confused with the game plan.

cons: Constant reorganization. Constant rumors of more layoffs on the way. Stabs to the back by co-workers fearful of loosing their job. Extreme lack of innovation. Ethics . . . OMG, there are NONE. Dell is a company in decline. I'm gone and I would never, ever go back.
advice: I wouldn't know where to begin. Dell needs ETHICS. They need redone from top to bottom. Get rid of the constant chaos so that your best employees WANT to stay.
pros: The pay and benefits were pretty good and work hours and days pretty flexible, but I value my sanity too much to ever go back.
summary: Chaos, Chaos, Chaos

cons: Constant reorganization. I have 20+ direct reports so I really don't have the cycles to do any one aspect of my job well. Dell is a technical company hard to stay sharp on the latest and greatest.
advice: I need a secretary
pros: Dell allowed flexibility in my schedule to allow for military reserve (retired) duties. Dell promoted me beyond my abilities and allowed me to grow into the position tolerated my mistakes along the way. Pay and bonuses are terrific. Lots of time off. Most people don't take all the time off Dell gives them but I do. Region is so big it is hard for anyone to keep track of what i really do. Lots of time to work from hom… e.
summary: To much reorganization

cons: Everything Else. No Promotions. No Opportunities. Offshoring all functions. Nothing gets completed. Constant Management Shuffle. Consistent "HURRY UP AND WAIT"
advice: Vision of Leadership is not cascaded to all employees. Demotivated workforce. Internal models not working. Stock price indicative of future.
pros: Salary. Pay is competitive. However, Total Compensation is below average. Cost of Health Benefits increasing. Took Away Annual Cash Bonus.
summary: Not Memorable

cons: Downsizing employee base without downsizing workload. Prior to 2001, Dell wasn't a bad place to work because tech stocks were still over-inflated. Once the tech stocks bombed, Dell started it's cutbacks. Lay-offs became more common and when your department was downsized, you simply took on a greater workload. 70 hour weeks were the norm (as a salaried employee, the pay is the same for 40 hours or 140 hours a week). P… erformance plan goals are impossible to achieve, which gives Dell the opportunity to rate your performance poorly, which equates to no annual raise or bonus if you are even eligible to begin with.Dell is still a good ole boy network and diversity among the most upper management is non existent.The atmosphere within my department was very immature and several employees were bullied by their coworkers. Management and HR refused to do anything about it.It turned out to be the absolute worst working environment I have ever endured..
advice: Folks, you need to get your act together. Perhaps those multi-million dollar salaries of the higher ups could be cut instead of downsizing the employees that do the real work.
pros: Pay and benefits are very competitive.
summary: Workload is overwhelming while upper management rakes in the big bucks.
role: Want A Nervous Breakdown, Get A Job At Dell

cons: Very competitive, to the point that you aren't sure who to trust. I had a manager title, but did not manage anyone. All of the people managers had an agenda and were ready to step on anyone who got in their way.
advice: Managers at Dell need to learn to do more than pretend they care about their employees, they need to realize they are people.
pros: Benefits/ pay. Very bright workforce
summary: Dog eat dog

cons: the work culture embraces divide and conquor mentality, does not embrace intellectual reasoning and sound logic (rather: the leader of the pack has the final say, often based on politics, not science). extremely dense political atmosphere: you either play the game and brown nose management, and pray that if the stars are all aligned, you'll get the promotion you have been hoping for, or remain at the same level for y… ears. total lack of talent management. non-intellectually challenging environment. anyone with higher degrees are advised to avoid working there. managers do not know how to supervise staff with higher degrees.
advice: culture needs a total over-haul: the zero-sum game played by employees and management alike is detrimental to the company, stock holders and technology innovation. why is no one embracing the win-win strategy? :O in fact, there's a total absence of technology innovation and incentive for employees to work in the best interest of the company (complete lack of: metritocracy, people management skills and talent manageme… nt skills). change the culture (from top to bottom; esp. top!) to a win-win culture from an internal zero-sum game culture and you'll see the company turn around.
pros: average pay and benefits. good flex time.

cons: Dell has been adding "services" to their hardware/software mix for some time. In layman's terms this means call centers/customer service help desks for outside clients, some quite large. With over 20 years of exemplary work in various facets of IT, I was a casualty of the recession and was hired by the first company I applied to, Dell. I had never worked in a call center environment before and hoped for the best but … I was not prepared for the actuality.Every call center stereotype you may have heard of is there: literally chained to a 3x6 desk by a headset; calls, breaks and lunches timed to the millisecond; absolutely no privacy as you are only separated from your co-worker by an 8" divider; very often no time to breathe between calls, etc. There are agents who concentrate on email/web inquiries instead of the phones and that is seen as a perk and is relative heaven compared to the phone agents' world, but a web ticketer may still be tossed into the phone mix when they are short-staffed; even if not trained in that realm they are still audited/graded on the same standard as normal phone agents. Standards/requirements can change on a daily basis, making something that was correct one day be counted off for the next. We are required to have several certifications and even a year later a large minority of co-workers still do not have them yet they are still around.Actual competence is not rewarded but sticking as close to the metrics as possible is. Innovation/real world experience from the few "adults" on the floor who seek to improve processes is not sought out nor appreciated. Mandatory overtime is required more than most would like. A cursory walk along the building will show desks with jackets, blankets and gloves worn by agents trying to stay warm year-round due to wacky climate control.One changes schedules, managers and tier 2 agents every three months which doesn't give one much time to build a relationship with someone who will champion you. Audits are handled by tier 2 agents who can either stick to the letter of the law or give out blanket top scores depending on who it is; their rankings are affected by how good/bad their agents' scores are and some pad the results while some are so hyper-critical one cannot compete fairly with the fluffed-up ones. As a person who strives for perfection and fairness, this disparity upsets me to no end. After bringing up examples of this to management ad nauseum, nothing changes and I am finding myself worn down from trying and from even caring. Anecdotally, with rare exception, all managers and tier 2 agents are married males, under 35 with small children. Take that as you will.To be fair to Dell, this is probably how all large call centers are run; agents are numbers, metrics and rankings. In a company of over 100,000, how much is one person going to matter? This is not an atmosphere for anyone who has ever held a real career-type job where one is treated like an adult, allowed to think and contribute. It will kill any enthusiasm you hold for doing an excellent job and it will kill your spirit. If quality of work life means anything to you, don't be lulled by the (sadly) decent wages by today's standards; keep looking. And if you are over 40, RUN!
advice: Realize that even some lowly customer services agents may have experience worth utilizing. Some of us only landed at Dell because of the recession yet bring years, sometimes decades, of experience that is being squelched and in turn the professional pride you hope to engender in your employees dies instead.
pros: Dell offers an above average benefits package, (surprisingly) higher pay than others for similar work and does walk their "diversity talk", at least as far as hiring goes.
